figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: All informal caregiver interventions included in the meta-analysis. Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: Subgroup analysis of all informal caregiver interventions that included an active control group. Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.

figure_4.title: Figure 4.
figure_4.caption: Subgroup analysis of interventions for informal caregivers of people with dementia/Alzheimer's disease, individual/group: All Studies. Mean within-group changes and standard.

figure_5.title: Figure 5.
figure_5.caption: Subgroup analysis of interventions for informal caregivers of people with severe mental illness, group/individual: All studies. Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.

figure_6.title: Figure 6.
figure_6.caption: Subgroup analysis of interventions with an individual delivery format: All studies. Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.

figure_7.title: Figure 7.
figure_7.caption: Subgroup analysis of interventions with a group delivery format: All studies. Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.

figure_8.title: Figure 8.
figure_8.caption: Subgroup analysis of interventions that were manualized and ≥8 weeks duration, group/individual: All studies. Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.

figure_9.title: Figure 9.
figure_9.caption: Subgroup analysis of interventions that were non-manualized interventions, ≤8 weeks of duration, individual/group delivery format: All studies. Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.

claims.sentence:
To investigate if high heterogeneity was associated with the quality of included RCTs, we conducted a sensitivity analysis and excluded RCTs of poor quality (e.g., unclear risk of bias on either sequence generation, allocation concealment, incomplete outcome data, or selective outcome reporting).Results
Study selection
The search yielded a total of 2,148 studies (Figure 1).

A total of 116 were excluded for the following reasons: not meeting the inclusion criteria for study design (n = 38), intervention (n = 34), patient population (n = 27), outcome (n = 13), and route of administration (n = 4) (Figure 1).
We found a statistically significant pooled effect favoring the intervention over waitlist, treatment as usual, or active control: −0.32 (95% CI −0.53 to −0.11) (Figure 2).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 89%, suggesting an even more substantial heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
We found a statistically significant pooled effect estimate favoring the intervention compared to an active control group: −0.24 (95% CI: −0.48 to 0) (Figure 3).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 0%, suggesting no heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.Figure 3.

The first included interventions for informal caregivers of people with dementia/Alzheimer's disease (17 studies, N = 1,049) and showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring interventions for informal caregivers of people with dementia/Alzheimer's disease, −0.2 (95% CI: −0.34 to −0.05) (Figure 4).

The second included all interventions for informal caregivers of people with a severe mental illness (15 studies, N = 823) and showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring interventions for informal caregivers of people with a mental illness, −0.68 (95% CI: −1.19 to −0.16) (Figure 5).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 96%, suggesting an even more substantial heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).

The third subgroup analysis included all interventions with an individual delivery format (12 studies, N = 828) and showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring individual interventions, −0.38 (95% CI: −0.64 to −0.11) (Figure 6).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 4%, suggesting no heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).

The fourth subgroup analysis included all interventions with a group delivery format (19 studies, N = 932) and showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring group interventions, −0.43 (95% CI: −0.8 to −0.07) (Figure 7).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 95%, suggesting an even more substantial heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
The results showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring interventions ≥8 weeks long and manualized, −0.38 (95% CI: −0.56 to −0.2) (Figure 8).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 2%, suggesting a low heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
The results did not show a statistically significant pooled effect favoring interventions ≤8 weeks long and non-manualized, −0.31 (95% CI: −0.79 to 0.17) (Figure 9).
The sensitivity analysis with exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 96%, suggesting an even more substantial heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
Mean within-group changes and standard.Figure 5.
Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.Figure 6.
Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.Figure 7.
Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.Figure 8.
Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.Figure 9.

Results
Study selection
The search yielded a total of 2,148 studies (Figure 1).

A total of 116 were excluded for the following reasons: not meeting the inclusion criteria for study design (n = 38), intervention (n = 34), patient population (n = 27), outcome (n = 13), and route of administration (n = 4) (Figure 1).

The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 89%, suggesting an even more substantial heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
We found a statistically significant pooled effect estimate favoring the intervention compared to an active control group: −0.24 (95% CI: −0.48 to 0) (Figure 3).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 0%, suggesting no heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.Figure 3.

The first included interventions for informal caregivers of people with dementia/Alzheimer's disease (17 studies, N = 1,049) and showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring interventions for informal caregivers of people with dementia/Alzheimer's disease, −0.2 (95% CI: −0.34 to −0.05) (Figure 4).

The second included all interventions for informal caregivers of people with a severe mental illness (15 studies, N = 823) and showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring interventions for informal caregivers of people with a mental illness, −0.68 (95% CI: −1.19 to −0.16) (Figure 5).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 96%, suggesting an even more substantial heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).

The third subgroup analysis included all interventions with an individual delivery format (12 studies, N = 828) and showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring individual interventions, −0.38 (95% CI: −0.64 to −0.11) (Figure 6).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 4%, suggesting no heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).

The fourth subgroup analysis included all interventions with a group delivery format (19 studies, N = 932) and showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring group interventions, −0.43 (95% CI: −0.8 to −0.07) (Figure 7).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 95%, suggesting an even more substantial heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
The results showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring interventions ≥8 weeks long and manualized, −0.38 (95% CI: −0.56 to −0.2) (Figure 8).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 2%, suggesting a low heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
The results did not show a statistically significant pooled effect favoring interventions ≤8 weeks long and non-manualized, −0.31 (95% CI: −0.79 to 0.17) (Figure 9).
The sensitivity analysis with exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 96%, suggesting an even more substantial heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).

Study selection
The search yielded a total of 2,148 studies (Figure 1).

A total of 116 were excluded for the following reasons: not meeting the inclusion criteria for study design (n = 38), intervention (n = 34), patient population (n = 27), outcome (n = 13), and route of administration (n = 4) (Figure 1).
The search yielded a total of 2,148 studies (Figure 1).

A total of 116 were excluded for the following reasons: not meeting the inclusion criteria for study design (n = 38), intervention (n = 34), patient population (n = 27), outcome (n = 13), and route of administration (n = 4) (Figure 1).
We found a statistically significant pooled effect favoring the intervention over waitlist, treatment as usual, or active control: −0.32 (95% CI −0.53 to −0.11) (Figure 2).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 89%, suggesting an even more substantial heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
We found a statistically significant pooled effect estimate favoring the intervention compared to an active control group: −0.24 (95% CI: −0.48 to 0) (Figure 3).
The sensitivity analysis with the exclusion of RCTs with poor quality resulted in an I2 of 0%, suggesting no heterogeneity among the included RCTs (Supplementary Figure 1).
Mean within-group changes and standardized mean differences.Figure 3.

The first included interventions for informal caregivers of people with dementia/Alzheimer's disease (17 studies, N = 1,049) and showed a statistically significant pooled effect favoring interventions for informal caregivers of people with dementia/Alzheimer's disease, −0.2 (95% CI: −0.34 to −0.05) (Figure 4).
